    UK: Southampton International Boat Show begins, until September 22; Cheltenham International Film Festival begins, until September 22; Harrogate Autumn Flower Show opens, until Sunday.

    On this day

    In 1663 a plot by European indentured servants, African slaves and Native Americans to confront their tobacco plantation masters in Virginia was foiled when they were betrayed. Known as the Gloucester County Conspiracy, it was the first recorded act of rebellion by such a group; in 1672 John Bunyan, the author of The Pilgrims Progress and a Puritan preacher, was formally pardoned after 12 years imprisonment during a period of religious intolerance; in 1848 a blast sent a 1.1m-long tamping iron through the skull of the US railroad foreman Phineas Gage. On being taken to the nearest doctor, Gage said: Doctor, here is business enough for you. A coffin was prepared, but he survived until May 21, 1860, aged 36; in 1944 Noor Inayat Khan, the first female Special Operations Executive wireless operator to be sent from the UK into enemy-occupied France to aid the French Resistance during the Second World War, was executed aged 30 with three other female agents. She had landed in France on June 16, 1943. She was posthumously awarded the George Cross in 1949 for displaying the most conspicuous courage, both moral and physical; in 2014 Islamic State released a video that showed the killing of the British hostage David Haines, an aid worker who had been abducted the previous year.

    Nature notes

    One of the loveliest signs of early autumn is the fall of birch seed. With each individual tree able to create millions of tiny seeds, the air can be full of this fine-grained snow. Winged to enable travel, the seeds are able to ride gusts for a good few hundred metres. Pollen records indicate that birches were the first trees to colonise Britain after the ice sheets withdrew more than 11,000 years ago, their winged seeds being blown further and further north. The same mobility can be seen now as the ice cap shrinks in the Arctic. In northern Norway, downy birch trees (Betula pubescens) are migrating north over the unfreezing tundra at an estimated rate of about 40-50 metres a year.

    Jonathan Tulloch
